question: I was suffering an identity crisis of my own. My gift for languages made me highly sought after. The C.I.A. and U.N. were both heavily recruiting Russian immigrants. Naturally, I went with the U.N. They were paying more. The fastest way to find out you can't change the world is to actually go there. West Africa's Liberia, or "land of the free", was originally established in the 1800's as a homeland for freed American negroes. It's been enslaved by one dictator or another ever since. They even copied their masters' Southern architecture. It was my first meeting with the American- educated Andre Roosevelt Baptiste. While the warning signs were all there, no one had any idea what a monster he would eventually become. I certainly didn't think he would become my friend.
answer: --World order? You say we jeopardize world order? I am only going to the restroom.

question: Orders.
answer: This is what they mean by U.N. Observer? Aren't you going to help me hold my cock?

question: Doesn't look like a job for two men.
answer: You know you are fighting a losing battle, my young friend. War is nature. If you take away the guns, we will kill each other with knives. Take away the knives, we will kill each other with sticks. Take away the sticks, we will kill each other with your peace treaties. You cannot stop this bath of blood.

question: It's not "bath of blood". It's, "blood bath".
answer: Thank you. But I like it my way.

question: For the smile. Fuck, no, no, no, no--fuck, no. Money? You want money? Fuck, no. Don't shoot. Don't shoot me. Fuck. U.S. dollars. President Lincoln.
answer: Glock .45.

question: What?
answer: President Jackson.

question: No.
answer: You are driving a hard bargain.

question: No, keep it. Keep the money. Keep the gun.
answer: What do you take me for - a thief? Demand and supply. There is more I am thinking where this comes from.

question: You want more Glocks?
answer: And the Heckler & Koch G-3 assault rifle.

question: What makes you think I'll do that?
answer: I will come back and shoot you with the Glock. By the way, do you have the hollow point cartridges?

question: You got any color preference for that?
answer: Kelly green. I will find you.

question: He'd come to the right place - peacekeepers are armed to the teeth. And nothing but premium product. The U.N. mostly buys from Switzerland - where else?
answer: What are we doing here, Yuri?

question: Whatever you want.
answer: You know what I mean. Here, in this country. Are we doing any good?

question: You know who's going to inherit the earth?
answer: It's a hell of a fucking career move.

question: That's the point. I've seen how the world's coming apart.
answer: And you want to help with that?

question: You can't stop it. It's a basic human need - we eat, sleep, sleep with each other and what else? Fight. The oldest human skeletons have spearheads in their rib cages.
answer: What do you know about guns?

question: I know which end I'd rather be on. Every day there are people shooting at each other. I think to myself, what guns are they using? Why not mine?
answer: I don't know.

question: Vitaly, I've tasted your borscht, you're no fucking chef. I can eat here for free and I still don't eat here. You're doing nothing with your life.
answer: Maybe doing nothing's better than doing this. Yuri, I've actually fired one of these things.

question: Yob tvayu mat. Curious how you always revert to your native tongue in moments of extreme anger... ...and ecstacy.
answer: Boh...Boh. Oh, Boh!

question: Vitaly and I found our niche in under-the- counter gunrunning - regimes suffering under sanctions. The job wasn't so different trom the U.N. I was just as neutral working for the ununited nations. An equal opportunity "merchant of death", I supplied every army but the Salvation Army. We got our start in Lebanon after the suicide bombing. When the United States leaves a war zone, they generally don't take their munitions. It costs more to bring it back than buy new stock. I sell by the kilo. For all my language skills, I soon discovered that what talks best is money. As long as you can speak dollars, dinars, drachmas, rubles, rupees, pesos, escudos, lira, krones, kwanzas, trancs, guilders, deutshmarks, yen and pounds-fucking- sterling, you can communicate anywhere in the world. This is bullshit money, Vit - small fucking potatoes.
answer: What do we do, go more legitimate?

question: No. More illegal.
answer: What I'd give right now for a plate of red cabbage and potatoes.

question: It's not our fight. I sold Israeli-made Uzis to Muslims. I sold to both Pakistan and India in their fight tor the most inhospitable land on earth. How's it going? Make sure you thaw out the guns before you fight. We had our set-backs. It's not called gunrunning for nothing. Cannibal, what's going on? What?! What do you mean it's over? Friends?! You can't be fucking friends. Last week I spoke to you on the phone. You said you would not rest until every last rebel was dead. You called them vermin. You said would piss in their mouths, you said you would exterminate them like cockroaches. Just last week, you said this! Cannibal, don't you fucking walk away from me! Fuck you, Cannibal!!
answer: Maybe we can offload it - the Balkans.

question: At least when they say they're going to have a war, they keep their word. I even shipped cargo to Afghanistan when they were still fighting fellow Russians. But I never sold to Osama bin Laden. Not for any moral grounds. Back then he was always bouncing checks. Personal use. I'm kind of trigger happy. And everywhere I went, Ava Cordova kept following me around. We were as international as each other. Operations like mine provided the only way for certain regimes to conduct a respectable war. The freighter I was standing on carried 113 tons of weapons and ammunition for delivery to one of the poorest nations in Latin America in direct contravention of half a dozen international arms embargoes. To keep authorities in the dark, I often spoke in code. Rocket launchers were "mothers", the rockets "children". Assault rifles were "apples". The AK-47 was "the Angel King". The Angel King will arrive tomorrow...Hallelujah to you too.
answer: We have to get out of here.

question: No, no-one's going anywhere. Slow--dead slow. Buy me time.
answer: Yuri!

question: What?!
answer: I've got Belgium.

question: What the fuck use is that?! He's painting a name registered in the fucking Netherlands!
answer: Yes, why?

question: Fuck you!
answer: No, you don't fuck him-- The first and most important rule of gunrunning is never get shot with your own merchandise. The second rule is always ensure you have a foolproof way to get paid. Credit card, check, cash. Preferably in advance, ideally to an off-shore account. It's why I choose my customers so carefully. Say what you like about warlords and dictators, they tend to have a highly developed sense of order. They always pay their bills on time.

question: I apologize for earlier.
answer: I understand.

question: It's all there.
answer: What is this?

question: Six keys of pure.
answer: I can't hand this to my fucking bank teller at Chase Manhattan.

question: You should be thanking me. Have you checked the street price today? With the seizures at the border last week, it's jumped thirty percent.
answer: I sell guns. I don't sell drugs.

question: Diversify.
answer: I've got standards.

question: I've got standards.
answer: Now what?

question: Vit. I found Vitaly twelve days, two thousand miles and 150 grams later in a Bolivian boarding house. Vitaly! Open this fucking door!
answer: Yuri! It's my brother, Yuri. He's my big brother.

question: What the fuck is that?
answer: Ukraine. I start in Odessa, work my way to the Crimea--

question: --You'll be fucking dead before you reach Kiev.
answer: You fuck!

question: Get out of the car.
answer: Please.

question: Vitaly, you're going to have a good time. This is a top place. Two Ford models checked in last week and that cute weather girl's been here since July.
answer: Please. You're a good brother.

question: Popular hotel, huh?
answer: Yuri Orlov. What brings you to St. Barts?

question: A photo shoot. At least, that was the plan. But the photographer's plane got stuck in Miami. Hurricane - though there was nothing in the news.
answer: Those things can come out of nowhere.

question: The job's cancelled and there's no flight back to New York 'til Tuesday.
answer: You can hitch a ride with me if you like. In my experience some of the most successful relationships are founded on lies and deceit. Since that's where they usually end up anyway, it's a logical place to start. I nearly went broke trying to convince her I was anything but. I knew Ava was not the kind of woman to be seduced by a ride in a private jet unless you owned the jet.

question: This is your plane?
answer: That is my name. Of course I was lying. The plane was a rental, like the car and even the suit I was standing in. At the last minute, I bribed the crew for the paint-job. Luckily, by the time we landed, Ava wasn't looking anywhere but in my eyes. I had no idea.

question: Don't apologize. I put on clothes for a living.
answer: At least you aren't taking them off.

question: I would be if half the photographers had their way. But I can't complain. I'm paid to say, "Cheese". What about you?
answer: Nothing so glamorous. I'm in transport - international air freight mostly.

question: What, like UPS or something?
answer: Something like that.

question: Business is good.
answer: Like you, I can't complain.

question: But if you did?
answer: Well...I don't know. It's just that I travel all around the world but I can't help feeling sometimes that I'm going nowhere.

question: This is no accident, is it, Yuri?
answer: I don't believe in fate.

question: What do you believe in?
answer: We married in a synagogue to make my father happy. In the eyes of my Catholic mother, it was worse than living in sin. It's traditional.

question: At least there'll be religious freedom.
answer: I think I'll go back for a visit. Do you stay in touch with Uncle Dmitri?

question: Dmitri Volkoff? Now and then.
answer: How is he?

question: The luckiest man alive. You know he was one of the first men at Chernobyl. Off-duty, at his daughter's wedding, he was roaring drunk. He was the only one who survived. Later they found that alcohol in your blood resists radiation.
answer: He's still a General in the army?

question: Major General. He got promoted. Two of his rivals were also there that day. I told you - he's the luckiest man alive.
answer: He may be luckier than you think.

question: We're not fools, Yuri. What's between you and your wife is your own business but I don't think you're going to Odessa to open a McDonald's. Is this how you want to be remembered?
answer: You're only remembered when you're dead.

question: I miss you too. There's no problem leading a double life. It's the triple and quadruple lives that get you in the end. Back then I carried a French, British, Israeli and Ukrainian passport and a student visa for the U.S., but that's another story. I also packed five different briefcases depending on the region of the world I was visiting. The end of the Cold War was the beginning of the hottest time in arms dealing. The Wall had fallen. The arms bazaar was open. Those forty-five years had generated the highest weapons build-up in history. The Soviets had tanks and guns coming out the demon hole - huge stockpiles and now no enemy. It's good to be home.
answer: Nephew, come here and hug the luckiest man alive. This is the SLK?

question: 0 - 60 in 4.8.
answer: I can't just sell you government property, Yuri. I have to report--

question: --Report to who? Moscow? As of last week Moscow is in a foreign country.
answer: New flag, new boss.

question: There is no new boss yet. They're too busy squabbling over who gets the presidential holiday home at the Black Sea. How many Kalashnikovs do you have?
Is that a "4"? It doesn't look like a "4" to me. It looks more like a "1".
answer: No, it's a "4".

question: It's whatever we say it is because no one else knows the difference.
answer: Someone will work this out, Yuri. What happens then?

question: We'll cut them in. Anyway, what could happen - you're the luckiest man alive. Avtomat Kalashnikova, model of 1947 - more commonly known as the AK-47 or Kalashnikov. It's the world's most popular assault ritle - a weapon all fighters love. An elegantly simple nine pound amalgamation of forged steel and molded plastic. It doesn't break, jam or over-heat. It will shoot whether its covered in mud or filled with sand. It's so easy, even a child can use it. And they do. The Russians put the gun on a coin. Mozambique put it on their flag. Since the end of the Cold War, the Kalashnikov has become the Russian peoples' greatest export - after that comes vodka and suicidal novelists. One thing's for sure, no one was lining up to buy their cars. Of course my idea was not entirely unique. I had rivals. He's a friend of mine.
answer: Do you know who the fuck I am? I demand to see your commanding officer. Just give me back my papers.

question: You're late, Simeon. Maybe you'd like to come to my room and see my bazooka. You look a little lost, Simeon. Is the world changing too fast?
answer: I am here, aren't I?

question: Not all of you, I think.
answer: I can't deny, it takes some getting used to. Last week we were trying to beat their brains in and now we're going into business together.

question: There's no place in gunrunning for politics anymore, Simeon. I sell to leftists, rightists. I'd sell to pacifists but they're not the most regular of customers.
answer: I understand you have Ukraine in your pocket but there are the other satellite states. Bulgaria, Hungary, Poland, Belarus. Instead of cutting each other's throats, it may be more profitable to work together. What do you think?

question: I think you are the amateur now. I think you suffer from a philosophical disadvantage - you have a philosophy. I think you should go with your instincts - your first instinct.
answer: The problem with gunrunners going to war is there's no shortage of ammunition.

question: Back then, it was all for sale... Helicopters, torpedo boats, armored personnel carriers, whole tank divisions.
answer: --I'll tell you what I'll do. Buy six, you get one free.

question: What about tech support?
answer: No problem.

question: Son, get off there before you get hurt.
answer: He's the tech support.

question: He's twelve.
answer: Thirteen. Almost fourteen.

question: Who are you?
answer: How can I? You keep selling my helicopters. You're too greedy, Yuri.

question: We have to go back.
answer: We'll be going in reverse. We can't turn around for a mile. We shoot it out?

question: And start an international fucking incident - no, no, no.
answer: So we run.

question: No. I've got paperwork.
answer: Not for the gunship. Yuri, you know the penalty for sanction-busting - selling a military helicopter?

question: It's not a military helicopter. It's a rescue helicopter. Yuri Orlov.
answer: Papers.

question: The crew called that vessel a lot of names - none of them repeatable in polite company.
answer: The end-user certificate for this aircraft states Burkina Faso. Nice. Did you type it yourself?

question: It's for humanitarian missions.
answer: You're a humanitarian?

question: Not any more.
answer: Listen to the nephew.

question: Didn't you get the memo? The war's over. What can they do with military hardware but convert to civilian use?
answer: What, yes?

question: The only way you could die from this baby is if a food drop hits you.
answer: Also going to Burkina Faso?

question: But to a different client at a different address.
answer: What do you take me for? A complete fucking fool?

question: Not complete, Sir. And while I hesitate to tell you your job, I must point out that when shipped separately the weapons and the aircraft both comply with the current Interpol trade standards and practices.
answer: You expect me to believe this is a coincidence?

question: I can see how certain people might interpret it as suspicious but thank God we live in a world where suspicion alone does not constitute a crime.
answer: Yuri Orlov. You and I are going to be seeing a lot of each other.

question: I can hardly wait.
answer: Watch out for the time you don't see me.

question: What was he doing here?
answer: Trying to beat your offer. I sent him on his way. He doesn't understand the concept of loyalty.

question: Don't worry. There're more VCR's. I left them in your new car.
answer: Even your enemy was admiring that car. I am the luckiest man alive.

question: Dmit--!!!
answer: Yes, I'll accept the charges.

question: Ava--
answer: Hey, baby. You forgotten what time it is?

question: Sorry. I, er... How was your audition?
answer: They're going in another direction. The direction of someone who can act.

question: Don't say that. You're good.
answer: And you're biased. Where are you? Is everything okay?

question: Rough day at the office.
answer: Come home. We miss you.

question: Soon. How's Nicki?
answer: Asleep in our bed. It's lonely without you.

question: A party.
answer: It's always a party where you are.

question: I'd better go. I just wanted to call--hear your voice. Kiss Nicki for me.
answer: I love you.

question: In Ukraine since 1992, $32 billion worth of arms have been stolen and re-sold. One of the greatest heists of the 20th Century. The primary market was Africa. Eleven major conflicts involving 32 countries in the past decade - a gunrunner's wet dream. My best customer was self-declared president of Liberia, Andre Baptiste. Even though we'd met before, I was in no hurry to meet him again. He'd gotten a reputation for routinely hacking off the limbs of those who opposed him. His seven-year civil war has been described as "a relentless campaign of sadistic, wanton violence unimaginable to those unfamiliar with the details of man's capacity to visit the abyss." That kind of sums up Andy for me. Thank him but I have other business. A busy schedule. What do you know? My schedule just freed up. But if I thought I was scared of Andre Senior, I knew I was scared of Andre Junior. Like father, like son. The guava doesn't fall too far from the tree. He was a heavy- drinker, a womanizer with a penchant for cheerleaders and a lover of fast American automobiles which he drove recklessly and with total impunity around the streets of the capital. Oh yes, he was also a cannibal. They say Andre would eat a victim's heart while it was still beating to give him superhuman strength. I could've told him he'd get the same effect from a pastrami sandwich at Carnegie's Deli. Monrovia itself was like being on another planet. Planet Monrovia. From the temperature it was obviously a planet close to the sun. I rarely saw another white man even at my hotel that was soon dubbed the "Little Kremlin". And I never left town alone. Outside town, was the edge of hell. I didn't want to even gaze into it. Part One, Two or Three? The M60. You want the attachable grenade launcher? In the most AIDS infested region of the globe, where one in four is infected, Andre's idea of a joke was to put a young Iman and a young Naomi naked in my bed and no condom within a hundred miles. How do you know? What if I have AIDS? Don't you worry? By leaving. --that's the Beretta, comes with a 36 cartridge, easy-operating clip--
answer: What did you say?

question: Now you're going to have to buy it. It's a used gun. I can't sell a used gun.
answer: A used gun. That's a good one.

question: I had heard of the "Boy Brigades", "Small Boy Units", "Kalashnikov Kids". The theory was that a bullet coming from a fourteen year old is just as effective as one trom a forty year old.
answer: I can't pay your asking price, Yuri. We are not a rich people and the market is already flooded with your Kalashnikovs. In some places you can buy one for the price of a chicken.

question: You can't just look at the unit price. You forget the ancillary costs. End user certificates need to be forged and notarized, shell companies set up, insurance purchased, pilots and crews hired. Not to mention the bribes. You can't get a nut and bolt out of the Eastern bloc without a bribe. There's one bribe for the nut. Another for the bolt. This is an expensive proposition.
answer: I pay in timber...or stones.

question: I'll take the stones. It's hard to get a tree trunk in my hand luggage.
answer: Very professional, Lieutenant.

question: I know you're planning a new offensive. If you delay a week I can get you the armored personnel carriers we talked about. They would give you a significant strategic advantage.
answer: They say I am the lord of war. But perhaps it is you.

question: It's not "lord of war". It's "warlord".
answer: I like it my way.

question: Diamonds are far less bulky than hundred- dollar bills. You can get a million dollars into a cigarette box. By the mid-nineties, my wealth had caught up to my lies about my wealth - even surpassed the lies.
answer: Yuri, I just got off the phone with the dealer. I sold my first painting.

question: Fantastic. Who bought it?
answer: Someone important. They want to remain anonymous. How was your trip?

question: You know. Same old, same old. Where's Nicki, in bed?
answer: I'm sorry. Poor darling. He tried to stay up.

question: I figured I was a patron of the arts and of everything else Ava had tried and failed at after modelling. Acting, her own cosmetics line. I didn't sabotage her careers but I can't deny it was convenient for me in maintaining a low profile. She was a beautiful bird in a gilded cage. How are you, brother?
answer: You know, still the resident family fuck-up.

question: Someone has to do it.
answer: She knows, right?

question: We don't talk about it.
answer: Shit, you're good. You almost had me convinced. We're going, baby.

question: To Manet, Monet...and Ava Cordova.
answer: Yuri!

question: The trip went better than expected.
answer: Yuri, they're beautiful. But what am I going to wear them with?

question: --Charlie, Echo, India. Descend for landing on heading zero...two...nine.
answer: Colonel Southern, it's Yuri. Sorry to call you on this number but I've got an Interpol jet and-- Not a good time!

question: --Charlie, Echo, India. Comply immediately. That was your last warning.
answer: Where was the first fucking warning?!

question: I'm putting us down.
answer: You land and we're all going away! I don't have paperwork!

question: We're in a flying fucking bomb! They're firing bullets at our bullets! Forget about going away! They shoot again, we're going away for good! I'm putting us down.
answer: Okay! Okay!--Fuck!!

question: This is Charlie Echo India. Descending on heading zero two nine.
answer: Not the airport. There. The highway. It's our only fucking hope.

question: A pothole could set us off.
answer: Don't underestimate yourself. You're the best, Tony.

question: Wait, you idiots! There's not going to be any evidence! Stay with the plane! Help yourselves. Be my guest. No charge. What a fucking disaster. Hey, not those! You don't touch the plane! Not the fucking seats...
answer: Hey, you! No, Mbizi. No, no, no. I can't do that. We will. No. Find the pilots.

question: What's the charge?
answer: What are you doing in Sierra Leone?

question: I'm on safari.
answer: Shooting wildebeests with submachine guns?

question: Are you with the park service? Hunting without a license - is that the charge?
answer: You're trafficking arms.

question: Trading. But without evidence who can say?
answer: Trade or traffic, you make a fortune by keeping the poorest people on the planet killing each other. Do you know why I do what I do?

question: I don't want people dead, Agent Valentine. I admit, a shooting war is better for business. But I'd prefer people to fire my guns and miss. Just as long as they're firing.
answer: I am legally permitted to hold you for twenty-four hours without charging you. You'll be pleased to know your colleagues were no more co-operative than you.

question: Yuri! Yuri Orlov!
answer: Vivian...

question: What are you doing here?
answer: You know. Fighting the good fight.

question: An aid program?
answer: Uh, yes. In fact, I've just had some transport problems. You couldn't give me a ride to Monrovia, could you?

question: Sure. Climb in.
answer: Jesus! Simeon! Me?! You stupid old fuck! No. No. No. I... Stop. I started doing a lot of cocaine in West Africa. I wasn't medicating myself. I was simply playing catch-up. I was constantly dealing with people who are chemically imbalanced without the aid of chemicals. It's just a matter of etiquette. It's rude to act sane in a room full of lunatics.

question: Jesus! Simeon! Me?! You stupid old fuck! No. No. No. I... Stop. I started doing a lot of cocaine in West Africa. I wasn't medicating myself. I was simply playing catch-up. I was constantly dealing with people who are chemically imbalanced without the aid of chemicals. It's just a matter of etiquette. It's rude to act sane in a room full of lunatics.
answer: He bought you "brown-brown", Mr. Yuri.

question: What?
answer: "Brown-brown".

question: What is it?
answer: A mixture - cocaine and gunpowder.

question: What does the gunpowder do?
answer: It's magic. They give it to the small boys before battle - they do anything.

question: Some other time.
answer: You have to try it at least once, Mr. Yuri.

question: Why?
answer: Because it's your gunpowder.

question: I'm going for a walk. I didn't fuck you, did I? Did I fuck you? Are you sick? Hello. Simeon. Yeah, fuck Andre. I'm sorry. They don't usually do that. Let me have a look. Maybe I can fix it.
answer: Yuri, you fucked up! I am going to shoot your face off with your own gun.

question: Not bad. Andre's latest double?
answer: How did you know?

question: He's too eloquent.
answer: You have no heart. Have you seen the news? They accuse me of rigging elections, but after this in your Florida with your Supreme Court of kangaroos--

question: More good news. That's the last aid shipment. The war is so bad, the U.N. is pulling out.
answer: Why is nothing happening?

question: Get out.
answer: Ava? Ava, what's wrong? Where's Nicki?

question: He's with your parents.
answer: Why aren't you dressed? I thought we were going out.

question: I can't wear the clothes. I can't wear the jewelry. I can't drive the car. I can't live in this house. Everything1s got blood on it.
answer: Don't be so melodramatic.

question: Of course I'm melodramatic. I'm a failed actress, remember? We need to talk about it.
answer: Why? We never have before.

question: Now we do.
answer: These people - you can't trust them--

question: --I've talked to your parents. Why do you think they don't want your money? They know where it comes from. We all know.
answer: I sell people a means to defend themselves, Ava. That's all. I don't hold a gun to any one's head and make them shoot--

question: --Yuri, I see the news. Sierra Leone--
answer: --I don't sell machetes.

question: --What do you think is pointing at the victims when they use those machetes? I see the pictures. Yuri, the guns are bigger than the boys.
answer: There's nothing illegal about what I do.

question: I don't care if it's legal, it's wrong. Please stop.
answer: It makes no difference if I stop. Someone will take my place the next day.

question: Let them. We have enough. You're not that little boy in Odessa anymore, lining up for a loaf of bread--
answer: --It's not about the money.

question: What is it?
answer: You can't leave. I'll stop. I'll stop.

question: You will? You promise?
answer: Yes. Now get dressed. We'll go out. For the next month I stopped running guns. I went legitimate. No wonder Valentine was confused. Thank God there are still legal ways to exploit developing countries. But the only problem with an honest buck is they're so hard to make. The margins are too low. Too many people are doing it. --Impossible. Two and a quarter? I can't make a profit at two and a quarter. Why don't you take my oil and I'll fucking pay you?

question: He's early. What the fuck are you doing here, Andre?
answer: We're here for the peace talks at the U.N.

question: So at the same time you thought you'd drop in on your arms dealer?!
answer: Is that what you still are? You're a hard man to get hold of all of a sudden. --But now you mention it, we are doing a little shopping while we're here - that is if you open for business.

question: They've got to be watching.
answer: Of course they blame me. They always blame me. They are on a--

question: --hunt for a witch?
answer: "Witch-hunt". But I have been granted diplomatic immunity due to the escalation in hostilities. That is why I need you. They are making life difficult to re-supply. It will require a man of your unusual ingenuity.

question: I can't help you. I'm sorry.
answer: I understand.

question: Was that about the oil or the timber?
answer: Both. Everything. At four and a half months a human fetus has a reptile's tail - a remnant of our evolution. You can fight a lot of enemies and survive but if you fight your biology you always lose. Hey, not even waiting to say goodbye? I'm leaving in ten minutes.

question: Sorry, Nicki has swim practice.
answer: See you, big guy.

question: Personally, I'm glad you're going. You've been here so long you're starting to get on my nerves.
answer: This oil concession should be wrapped up by Thursday. I'll be back for the weekend. We'll go somewhere - the sea.

question: That would be fun.
answer: You trust me, right? She looked me directly in the eye the way I've looked in the eyes of a thousand customs officials, government bureaucrats and footsoldiers from every law enforcement agency in the world - and she lied without flinching.

question: Yes, I trust you.
answer: She'd learned from the best.

question: That's him. It's a game. Yes.
answer: I can always sense when I'm being tailed. I know what to look for. But then I'd never been tailed by the woman I love. I can put myself in Ava's place. She might have understood if the combination was the last four digits of my social, my birthdate, even her birthdate but not Nicolai's. My son's birthday unlocked what the government would later describe as, "a catalogue of carnage".

question: Come to see how the other half lives?
answer: I miss your borscht. Mom and Dad say you're clean.

question: You too. They said you went legitimate - hard to believe.
answer: That's because it's not true. Only you know. I'm leaving tonight - on a job. I want you to come.

question: I can't. I'm thinking of opening my own place.
answer: Maybe this trip will help. It's good money.

question: I've given my word.
answer: They don't have to know. We'll tell them we're going for a little "r" and "r".

question: Why do you need me all of a sudden?
answer: West Africa's fucked-up. More than usual. I can't trust anybody. I need someone to watch my back. Where are we going? Every faction in Africa calls themselves by these noble names - "liberation-this", "patriotic-that", "democratic-republic-of- something or other". I guess they can't own up to what they usually are - "federation- of-worse-oppressors-than-the last-bunch-of- oppressors". Often the most barbaric atrocities occur when both combatants proclaim themselves "freedom fighters".

question: Jesus. Yuri, I need to talk to you.
answer: Not now.

question: Now.
answer: Excuse me. What?

question: We can't do this deal.
answer: The fuck we can't.

question: Look over there. As soon as we leave, they're going to die.
answer: It's not our business.

question: They killed a boy just now - as young as Nicki.
answer: There is no hold up. I'll be right there.

question: Today we can. They're right there - close enough to touch.
answer: What do you think they'll do if we back out - they'll kill us.

question: And if we go ahead - they'll kill them.
answer: Nothing.

question: Nothing. You're right, Yuri. You're right. Did I hear you say 300 IPG's, 500 assault rifles and 800 grenades? I thought it was 1,200 grenades. I'd better check. Something for Yuri.
answer: Vit!! Vitaly broke the cardinal rule of gunrunning. Never pick up a gun and join the customers. Coffins are hard to come by in Sierra Leone. Demand is so high. Fortunately, we had a lot of boxes just the right size. I don't know which is worse, Jewish guilt or Catholic guilt. My parents were like God's tag-team. But I could not deny them the chance to say goodbye to their eldest son. For twenty Monrovian dollars a doctor removed the lead from Vitaly's body and wrote a bogus death certificate. I should have paid more. I've smuggled millions of rounds of ammunition and the bullet that lands me in jail is found under my dead brother's rib. Believe it or not, I only use the first two.
